FSPL  III  is  fully  aligned  with  the  Government's  new  Socio-
Economic  Development  Plan  2006–2010  (SEDP),  approved  in 
2006,  which  not  only  targets  middle-income  status  by  2010  but 
also envisages industrial country status for Viet Nam by 2020. To 
achieve these goals the SEDP strongly emphasizes the objectives 
of  business  development,  private  investment,  and  a  continuing 
transition  to  a  market-based  system  with  greater  integration  with 
the  global  economy.  ADB's  country  strategy  and  program  for 
2007–2010 is congruent with the Government's SEDP, supporting 
business-led  pro-poor  growth  through  promoting  infrastructure 
development,  a  business-enabling  environment,  and  financial 
intermediation. 
 
 
The  objective  of  FSPL  III  is  to create  a  more  diversified,  deeper, 
and  more  resilient  financial  sector.  The  bank-dominated  financial 
sector  cannot  adequately  finance  the  economy’s  investment 
needs. FSPL III will lead to an increased share of capital markets 
in  the  financing  of  domestic  investment,  which  will  promote  and 
facilitate sustained high growth in the economy with reduced risks. 
Development of diversified capital markets will result in increased 
efficiency  of  financial  intermediation  in  the  economy,  more 
efficient  allocation  of  resources,  and  a  sound  macroeconomic 
environment that is more resilient to external and regional shocks. 
FSPL  III  will  also  support  Government  efforts  to  promote  greater 
regional cooperation through cooperation with regulators of other 
securities markets in the region. 
 
A  loan  of  $75,000,000  equivalent  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds 
resources  will  be  provided  for  subprogram  1  of  the  program 
cluster. The loan will have an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% 
per  annum  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  per  annum 
thereafter; a term of 24 years, including a grace period of 8 years; 
and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft Loan Agreement.  
 
The implementation period for the program cluster is from January 
2006  to  September  2010;  subprogram  1  is  expected  to  be 
completed  14  months  after  loan  effectiveness.  The  loan  for 
subprogram  1  will  be  released  in  two  tranches:  SDR  19,116,000 
upon  fulfillment  of  specified  first  tranche  release  conditions,  and 
SDR 28,674,000 subject to fulfillment of specified second tranche 
release  conditions.  Subprogram  2  will  be  submitted  for  Board 
consideration  approximately  30  months  after  the  effectiveness  of 
subprogram  1,  subject  to  adequate  progress  of  reforms  and  the 
Government’s readiness to continue with its reform agenda. 
 
The  Government  will  use  the  local  currency  counterpart  funds 
generated  by  the  loan  proceeds  to  meet  program  expenditures 
and associated costs of reform and to help maintain current social 
expenditure.

Development  of  capital  markets  and  a  diversified  financial  sector 
will  help  mobilize  resources  and  allocate  them  efficiently.  The 
increased financial intermediation will help Viet Nam achieve and 
sustain  its  ambitious  growth  program.  Well-developed  capital 
markets will provide government and private sector with access to 
medium-  and  long-term  funds,  thus  enabling  a  wider  variety  of 
projects  to  be  financed  in  the  economy.  They  will  also  provide 
competition to the banking system, thus contributing to increased 
efficiency  of  banking  and  of  the  financial  sector  as  a  whole. 
Government  debt  market  development  will  help  the  economy  by 
providing  a benchmark  yield  curve  that  can  help  pricing  of other, 
riskier assets, and contribute to development of markets for such 
assets. Successful development of the shorter-term debt markets 
will  help  increase  effectiveness  of  the  monetary  policy  and 
facilitate improved monetary policy management.

2. 
Viet Nam has continued its impressive economic performance this decade, with average 
gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  per  annum  exceeding  7%  during  2002–2006  and 
expected to exceed 8% during 2007–2010 (Table 1). This is consistent with the Government's 
objective of achieving middle-income status by 2010. The rapid growth has been accompanied 
by  a  stable  outlook  for  both  fiscal  and  external  balance,  and  a  remarkable  shift  towards  a 
market-oriented  economic  system,  through  wide-ranging  reforms  and  liberalization,  marked 
most  recently  by  the  country's  accession  to  the  World  Trade  Organization  (WTO)  in  January 
2007.  Poverty  in  Viet  Nam  has  declined  rapidly  in  the  past  decade,  from  37.4%  in  1998  to 
19.5% in 2004; other social indicators of development are also showing improvement, including 
infant and maternal mortality, child malnutrition (under 5 years), and access to safe water.

4. 
GDP growth in FY2006, estimated at 8%, was driven by strong demand, including 20% 
growth in exports in dollar terms. The ratio of exports to GDP increased from about 46% in 2000 
to  66%  in  2006,  indicating  growing  openness  of  the  economy  even  before  Viet Nam  joined 
WTO.  The  structure  of  exports  is  becoming  more  diversified;  commodities  such  as  crude  oil, 
rice, marine products, and coffee remain important, but the share of manufactured products is 
rising.  Exports  of  clothing,  electronics,  and  wood  products  each  expanded  by  at  least  20%  in 
2006.  Viet  Nam  is  committed  to,  and  benefiting  from,  growing  integration  with  the  global 
economy. 
 
5. 
Unlike several other economies in the region, Viet Nam's rapid growth is relatively more 
balanced,  driven  by  both  external  and  domestic  demand.  Rising  consumption  and  investment 
were  both  manifest  in  the  robust  growth  in  domestic  demand  in  FY2006.  Growth  in  private 
consumption  was  supported  by  rising  incomes  and  inward  remittances  of  about  $4 billion. 
Investment  remained  high  at  38.4%  of  GDP.  Private  investment,  which  now  comprises  more 
than  half  of  all  investment,  was  encouraged  by  further  simplification  of  administrative 
procedures  for  businesses  and  moves  toward  equality  of  treatment  between  state  enterprises 
and the private sector and between domestic and foreign enterprises. Domestic private sector 
growth has been accelerating and its share in GDP is increasing gradually. Additionally foreign 
direct  investment  commitments  rose  to  $10.2 billion  in  2006,  the  highest  since  the  country 
opened to investment in 1986.  
 
6. 
Inflation continues to be a concern, exceeding 7% on average during 2006 for the third 
year  in  a  row.  In  February  2007  inflation  declined  to  6.5%  but  then  rose  to  7.6%  in  June. 
Inflationary pressures reflect several factors, including growth in aggregate demand, high world 
commodity prices, and monetary expansion triggered by incomplete sterilization of the high and 
rising  capital  inflows  into  the  economy.  Administered  domestic  fuel  prices  were  raised  in  April 
and  in  August  2006  by  a  cumulative  18.5%,  and  then  reduced  twice  by  a  cumulative  12.5%. 
Subsidies have been largely eliminated for gasoline and kerosene, and the Government plans 
to  eliminate  fuel  subsidies  completely  next  year.  The  minimum  salary  of  civil  servants  was 
increased  by  30%  in  October  2006,  a  component  of  civil  service  reforms,  resulting  in  second-
round effects on private sector wages. Domestic credit grew by almost 42% in 2004 and more 
than 30% in 2005. The State Bank of Vietnam (SBV) imposed prudential standards in 2005 to 
curb rapid growth, requiring commercial banks to limit medium- and long-term lending to 40% of 
their  short-term  funds.  These  restrictions  combined  with  high  inflows  of  foreign  currency,  in 
terms of remittances and foreign direct investment, contributed to excess liquidity in the banking 
subsector that SBV reduced by issuing SBV bills and increasing reserve requirements in 2007.  
 
7. 
Viet Nam's strategy for sustaining its high growth into the future relies on attaining high 
investment,  of  as  much  as  40%  of  GDP,  including  public  investment.  Viet  Nam's  aggregate 
savings rate, about 36% of GDP in 2006, is lower than in some of the economies in the region 
but rising.2 Savings are likely to continue increasing in view of the favorable demographic profile 
of  the  country,  which  has  one  of  the  youngest  populations  in  Asia  with  more  than  65%  of  the 
population below 65 years of age. The median age of the population is expected to be only 29 
years in 2015 (compared with 37 years in the People’s Republic of China (PRC)), and the ratio 
of  working  to  dependent  population  is  expected  to  continue  rising  in  the  medium  term,  with  a 
favorable impact on aggregate savings ratios.

increasing,  the  ability  of  the  economy  to  sustain  high  growth  will  require  increased  financial

dominates the financial sector, will need to be complemented by growth in the capital markets, 
particularly  to  finance  needed  medium-  and  long-term  infrastructure  investments  by  both  the 
public  and  private  sectors.  The  increased  role  of  nonbank  financial  intermediation  in  the 
economy  will  be  essential  to  help  the  country  reach  its  investment  and  growth  objectives  in  a 
sustainable manner.

Sector Description and Performance  

A. 

10. 
Banking sector remains underdeveloped, though cautious and persistent reforms 
continue.  The banking sector has grown significantly since the adoption of the Law on Credit 
Institutions in 1998. The law allowed a variety of products to be offered by credit institutions and 
introduced  prudential  provisions 
including  capital  norms,  restrictions  on  asset/liability 
management,  deposit  insurance  and  limits  on  investments  by  credit  institutions  in  real  estate. 
The number of banks increased due to lowered entry barriers: there are currently 37 joint stock 
banks,  5  joint  venture  banks  and  31  foreign  banks  in  addition  to  5  state-owned  commercial 
banks (SOCBs) and two development and policy banks. Both loans and deposits of the banking 
sector  have  grown  rapidly  since  1998,  at  average  annual  growth  rates  exceeding  25  percent. 
The  share  of  SOCBs  has  been  declining,  though  they  still  dominate  the  banking  sector, 
accounting for nearly 70 percent of all deposits, and 69 percent of total lending in 2005; by way 
of  comparison,  SOCB  share  in  total  lending  was  73  percent  in  2001.  The  share  of  SOCB 
lending  going  to  state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs)  has  also  been  declining,  as  has  the 
importance of policy-based lending in their operations. 
 
11.

supervisory  framework  of  banking,  and  to  address  problems  of  nonperforming  assets,

on  sound  market  principles.3 Banking  reforms  have  acquired  added  urgency  given  Viet  Nam's 
commitment under WTO accession to liberalize foreign entry into its banking system from 2007.

be  equitized  and  international  prudential  standards  applied  by  2010.  In  preparation  for  the 
equitization  of  the  SOCBs,  the  standards  for  financial  disclosure  for  SOCBs  have  been

rapidly in the past 5 years, with high double-digit annual growth in premiums between 2002 and

13. 
High growth of the industry primarily reflects the low base at the start. The industry is still 
underdeveloped in terms of premium penetration (which is half that of the PRC and India,5 and

range  also  reflects  inability  of  the  industry  to  offer  genuine  long-term  risk  cover  due  to 
underdeveloped capital markets, which do not yet allow for insurance companies to match long-
term  liability  with  comparably  long-term  assets.  The  industry  is  now  exploring  sale  of 
investment-linked products, whose approval process along with relevant regulations is expected 
to be completed in the latter half of 2008.

Capital  Markets:  Heterogeneous  Growth,  Uniformly  Underdeveloped.  Securities 
trading  centers  (STCs)  were  established  in  2000  in  Ho  Chi  Minh  City  (HSTC),  and  in  2005  in

be the official over-the-counter market in the country; while HSTC will be the stock exchange. 
Starting  with  only  five  listed  companies,  HSTC  grew  modestly  to  26  listed  companies  by  late 
2004. Since then, with growing interest from international investors, both exchanges have grown 
rapidly, particularly in 2006; the index for HSTC (VNINDEX) rose from 307.5 in 2005 to 751.8 at 
the  end  of  2006,  an  increase  of  144%;  the  index  for  HaSTC,  which  is  much  smaller,  rose  by 
152%  from  96.2  to  242.9  during  the  same  period.  Total  company  listings  at  the  two  trading 
centers have increased four fold, from 44 to 193, between the end of 2005 and end 2006, while 
total market capitalization increased by almost 21 times (from D11 trillion to D231 trillion), or to 
25.0%  of  GDP  in  2006  compared  with  1.3%  at  the  end  of  2005.  The  extent  of  market 
exuberance  is  evident  from  noting  that  the  Government  had  initially  set  a  target  for  combined 
market capitalization of the two exchanges at 10 percent of GDP by 2010, which has been far 
exceeded  already.  The  country  now  has  55  securities  firms  and  18  fund  management 
companies. The regulated equity markets are, however, still among the smallest in the region7 
and small compared with the unregulated market for trading equity in Viet Nam. The latter grew 
out  of  the  ambitious  equitization  program  of  SOEs,  only  a  few  of  which  listed  in  the  formal 
exchanges.  
 
16. 
The  underdevelopment  of  capital  markets  is  particularly  manifest  in  the  markets  for 
government debt, and even more so in case of the corporate debt market. Outstanding bonds 
issued by the State Treasury, Vietnam Development Bank, and municipal governments totaled 
about  D125  trillion  at  the  start  of  2007,  an  increase  of  almost  635%  over  the  corresponding 
value for 2002.8 Nonetheless, outstanding government debt represents only about 13% of GDP. 
The  primary  market  for  government  securities  is  highly  segmented  due  to  multiple  issues  and 
differentiated channels of distribution. The State Treasury of the Ministry of Finance (MOF) has 
more  than  100  issues  per  year  of  dong-denominated  treasury  bills  of  6-,  9-,  and  12-month 
maturity,  and  bonds  with  maturity  of  2,  3,  5,  10,  and  15  years.  These  are  issued  through  four 
channels:  (i)  treasury-bill  auctions  through  SBV,  with  SBV  as  the  registrar;  (ii)  bond  auctions 
through the STCs with the State Securities Commission (SSC) as the registrar, (iii) underwriting 
through  syndicates  of  designated  banks  and  securities  firms  with  each  underwriter  as  the 
registrar,  and  (iv)  direct  placement  or  retails  sales  of  bonds  to  the  public  through  the  national 
network of 600 offices of the State Treasury with each office as the registrar. In addition, SBV 
issues its own short-term securities for purposes of liquidity management. Banks are the largest 
investors  in  the  primary  debt  market;  insurance  companies  have  a  significant  presence  in 
longer-term bonds.

High Transaction Costs 

23. 
Transaction  costs  in  Viet  Nam's  capital  markets  are  high:  the  bid-ask  spread,  for 
example, for 10-year government bonds was 22.5 basis points in 2006, compared with 2 basis 
points  in  Malaysia,  3  in  Thailand,  and  17  in  Indonesia.10 Reduction  in  costs  of  transacting,  in

2. 

Ineffective Issuance Framework 

28. 
Further development of deep and liquid debt markets in Viet Nam will require substantial 
improvements  in  the  framework  for  debt  issuance.  The  primary  market  for  government 
securities is highly segmented due to multiple issues and channels of distribution, and there are 
too  many  issues  relative  to  the  total  volume  of  debt,  resulting  in  more  than  400  outstanding 
issues listed. Benchmark issues of sufficient volume need to be developed to enhance liquidity. 
This  will  require  amendments  to  existing  government  regulations  that  constrain  buyback  of 
government securities as well as reopening of issues, in order to start issuing benchmark issues 
and  consolidate  and  restructure  the  large  number  of  outstanding  debt  issues  into  fewer  and 
more liquid securities. 
 
The  excessive  number  of  issuances  is  accompanied  by  lack  of  adequate  predictability 
29. 
about  the  schedule  of  debt  issues,  constraining  planning  by  market  participants.  Although  the 
total amount of new debt planned is evident at the start of the fiscal year from the Government's 
annual  budget,  planning  by  market  participants  is  constrained  due  to  the  limited  information 
about planned issuances during the year. MOF provides an issuance calendar with a horizon of 
only one quarter; however its credibility is affected by the Government not always sticking to the 
announced  calendar  if  market  conditions  appear  adverse.  Predictability  of  issuances  needs  to 
be improved both in terms of reliability of the schedule and its time horizon.  
 
30. 
Development of the primary debt market is further compounded by government efforts to 
simultaneously  control  the  quantity  and  price  of  debt  issued  by  imposing  interest  ceilings  on 
each issuance. In part this reflects government concerns about possible collusion among limited 
bidders  in  the  market,  but  the  price  controls  are  blatantly  harmful  to  market  development  and 
need to be removed as early as possible. Elimination of price controls and thence artificially low 
borrowing  costs  for  government  will  be  a  potent  signal  of  government  commitment  to  further 
development of bond markets.  
 
31.

that no meaningful benchmark yield curve is available to help price other, riskier assets in the 
economy.  Developing  this  benchmark  yield  curve  will  require  time,  but  needs  to  start  by

macroeconomic environment that is more resilient to external and regional shocks. FSPL III is 
consistent with and supports the Government's Action Plan for Securities Market Development 
2006–2010, which implements the SEDP 2006–2010 and the commitments of the Government 
under  bilateral  and  multilateral  (WTO)  agreements.  It  is  also  aligned  with  the  country  strategy 
and program 2007–2010, which highlights the need for supporting financial sector development 
to promote Viet Nam's economic growth. 
 
45. 
Capital markets trade financial claims across different points in time and states of nature 
and are therefore extremely information intensive. FSPL III encompasses components aimed at 
promoting the creation and dissemination of information required to enhance price discovery, as

77. 
As  the  financial  sector  in  Viet  Nam  continues  to  grow  in  sophistication  and  become 
increasingly  market  based,  the  Government  will  need  to  develop  a  comprehensive  framework 
for regulation and supervision. The financial industry is operating in a conglomerate form, while 
the regulatory framework is based on entity regulation, whereby a particular regulatory agency 
supervises only particular type(s) of institutions instead of particular types of functions. A more 
function-based approach to supervision is needed, as well as a shift to risk-based supervision 
methods, and to adoption of common risk-based capital adequacy approaches that minimize the 
possibility  of  regulatory  arbitrage.  Vigilance  is  needed  as  (i)  different  types  of  intermediaries 
begin  to  target  the  same  market;  and  (ii)  one  type  of  intermediary  (e.g.,  banks)  begins  to 
develop subsidiaries to enable it to serve different (e.g., securities) markets. The regulatory and 
supervisory  framework  must  allow  both  kinds  of  innovations  to  take  place,  but  consolidated 
supervision  is  needed  to  mitigate  risks.  A  variety  of  institutional  forms  can  be  envisioned  for 
consolidated supervision, and the Government will need to assess possible choices.

institutions on investing and on providing services in securities markets in Viet Nam.

FSPL  III  will  also  support  Viet  Nam's  participation  in  the  IOSCO  MMOU.  The  MMOU 
establishes  an  international  benchmark  for  cooperation  and  information  sharing  among 
securities regulators. Prior to signing the MMOU, member regulators must establish through a 
fair and stringent process that they have the legal and regulatory capacity to fulfill the MMOU’s 
terms  and  conditions.  This  process  requires  an  extensive  review  of  the  potential  legislative, 
regulatory,  and  institutional  obstacles  that  prevent  a  full  exchange  of  information  among 
securities regulatory agencies. Additionally, this exercise—through its identification process—is 
expected  to  provide  incentives  for  members  to  raise  their  respective  national  standards.  SSC 
will  conduct  an  assessment  of  its  ability  to  meet  benchmarks  under  the  IOSCO  MMOU  and 
identify impediments. Subprogram 2 will support Viet Nam to become a signatory to Appendix B 
of the MMOU.

81. 
FSPL  III  has  a  number  of  distinct  features,  starting  with  its  strong  alignment  with  the 
Government's  own  action  plan  for  development  of  the  securities  markets.  In  addition  to 
reinforcing Government ownership and commitment to FSPL III, this also reiterates ADB's role 
as  a  consistent  development  partner  in  promoting  financial  sector  growth  and  development  in 
the country. Viet Nam's financial sector has been transforming at a rapid pace for a decade and, 
through  its  past  and  current  financial  sector  programs,  ADB  continues  an  active  role  in  both

86. 
The overall loan size as well as tranching arrangements are determined by the strength 
of  the  associated  policy  actions,  their  development  impact,  the  importance  of  the  sectors 
covered,  and  the  development  financing  needs  of  the  Government  as  indicated  by  MOF. 
According  to  MOF  budget  reports,  the  Government's  aggregate  financing  gap  for  2007  is 
approximately  $3.47  billion,  of  which  it  will  finance  $2.64  billion  through  domestic  borrowings

reforms are considerable, with vested interests benefiting from weak enforcement of regulations 
in  financial  markets  and  from  the  absence  of  adequate  risk-management,  supervision,  and 
transparency. Although the benefits of the reforms will far outweigh the costs, the benefits will 
materialize only over time, while the costs are front loaded. In the absence of timely reforms, the 
financial  sector  will  continue  to  be  ineffective  in  intermediating  resources  efficiently  into 
investments, the financial sector and the economy will be vulnerable to systemic risks, perhaps 
most  importantly  currency  and  maturity  mismatches,  and  investors  will  be  left  vulnerable  to 
market misconduct and fraud.

V. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Benefits and Impacts 

101.  The development of capital markets and a diversified financial sector will help mobilize 
resources and allocate them efficiently; the increased financial intermediation will help Viet Nam 
achieve and sustain its ambitious growth program. Well-developed capital markets will provide 
government  and  private  sector  with  access  to  medium-  and  long-term  funds,  thus  enabling  a 
wider  variety  of  projects  to  be  financed  in  the  economy.  They  will  also  provide  competition  to 
banking,  thus  contributing  to  increased  efficiency  of  banking  and  of  the  financial  sector  as  a 
whole. Government debt market development will help the economy by providing a benchmark 
yield  curve  that  can  help  pricing  of  other,  riskier  assets,  and  contribute  to  development  of 
markets  for  other  assets.  Successful  development  of  debt  markets  will  also  help  increase 
effectiveness  of  the  monetary  policy  and  facilitate  improved  monetary  policy  management. 
Increased investor protection in securities markets will benefit large as well as small investors, 
and  provide  households  with  mechanisms  to  invest  savings  safely.  Stronger  protection  for 
consumers in insurance will benefit all consumers, while enabling new insurance products to be 
introduced  to  the  market.  Development  of  the  leasing  sector  will  provide  access  of  firms, 
including  small-  and  medium-sized  firms,  to  alternative  sources  of  financing  for  their  capital 
requirement.  
 

 

 102.  FSPL III will also have the benefit of contributing to improved institutional coordination in 
the economy, particularly between MOF and SBV, as also between various regulatory agencies 
involved  in  supervising  the  financial  sector.  The  emphasis  of  FSPL  III  on  creation  and  large-
scale,  web-based  dissemination  of  information  across  the  financial  markets  is  another 
significant aspect of institutional change, given the historical context of Viet Nam as an economy 
in  transition.  By  encouraging  a  movement  away  from  hoarding  data  on  presumption  of 
sensitivity, the implementation of FSPL III will help contribute to institutionalizing enhanced data 
and information availability, and transparency across other markets and sectors of the economy, 
as  well  as  government  agencies.  Equally,  the  benefits  of  FSPL  III  will  be  spread  across  all 
sectors  of  the  economy,  given  the  role  of  the  financial  sector  in  modern  market-based 
economies.

3. 
Viet  Nam's  economic  transition  since  the  late  1980s  is  characterized  by  cautious  yet 
persistent reform initiatives, sequenced in terms of a focus initially on the needs of the domestic 
real  sector,  followed  later  by  more  complex  financial  sector  reforms.  Financial  reforms  for 
banking  started  in  the  mid-1990s,  at  the  same  time  as  development  of  capital  markets. 
However, the pace of reforms across the financial sector has picked up considerably during this 
decade. The Asian Development  Bank (ADB) strategy for financial sector development in Viet 
Nam comprises long-term commitment through the finance sector program loans (FSPLs) and 
advisory technical assistance with a focus initially on establishing the financial infrastructure and 
legal and regulatory framework. 
 
4. 
The  current  state  of  financial  sector  development  and  reform  indicates  continued 
modernization  of  banking  and  a  transition  to  the  intermediate  stage  of  capital  market

are  expected  to  be  characterized  by  improved  liquidity  in  key  areas,  extended  product  range, 
beginnings of active secondary markets, expanded institutional demand through insurance and 
pensions, increased domestic players including joint ventures, and enhanced transparency with

5. 
Over the longer term, Viet Nam needs to continue reforms to move to the mature stage 
of  capital  market  development,  with  liquidity  in  many  areas  of  the  market,  extended  product 
range  including  complex  derivatives  and  asset  backed  securities,  secondary  mortgages, 
presence  of  global  players,  and  full  transparency.  In  the  process,  the  Government  needs  to 
develop  a  vision  of  a  prospective  structure  of  the  financial  sector  over  a  longer  term,  and  to 
design  an  appropriate  regulatory  and  supervisory  structure.  In  particular,  regulation  and 
supervision  need  to  be  consolidated  to  remove  any  opportunities  for  regulatory  arbitrage.  The 
financial industry is operating in a conglomerate form, while the regulatory framework has been 
based  on  entity  regulation,  whereby  a  particular  regulatory  agency  supervises  only  particular 
types  of  institutions  instead  of  particular  types  of  functions.  For  example,  the  State  Securities 
Commission (SSC) regulates a brokerage subsidiary of a bank, but not the bank itself. Similarly, 
insurance companies are regulated by the Ministry of Finance (MOF), and are planning to start 
issuing  investment-linked  products  similar  to  mutual  funds,  which  would  fall  under  the 
jurisdiction  of  the  securities  regulator.  With  greater  financial  sophistication,  different  types  of 
financial institutions may move into a specific type of financial activity, and regulation needs to 
be  function  based.  Regulations  should  also  ensure  prudential  management,  governance, 
transparent trade, and fair competition within and between different conglomerates. To increase 
coordination  between  different  regulators,  the  Government  may  need  to  assess  choices 
between a unified regulatory agency and specialist agencies with coordinating mechanisms.

Starting  in  1989,  banking,  with  State  Bank  of  Vietnam  (SBV)  as  the  monobank 
conducting  both  central  and  commercial  banking,  was  changed  into  a  two-tier  system

comprises 5 state-owned banks, 37 joint stock banks, 5 joint venture banks, 31 foreign banks 
(branch offices), and two development and policy banks. In addition, nonbank credit institutions 
include  finance  companies;  financial  leasing  companies;  and  the  People's  Credit  Fund,  which 
focuses primarily on rural areas and provides credit and deposit services with a limited scope. 
 
9. 
The Law on Credit Institutions, adopted in 1998, provides the legal basis for operations 
of  both  local  and  foreign  credit  institutions,  and  provides  detailed  operating  guidance  to 
authorized  bodies.  The  law  provides  detailed  stipulations  on  licensing  and  regulations  for  the 
banking  businesses  such  as  refunding,  internal  audit  and  inspection,  SBV  supervision, 
prudential requirements, dissolution, bankruptcy, and liquidation. The law specifies powers and 
responsibilities  of  credit  institutions  as  a  legal  basis  to  conduct  banking  operations.  The 
Government is planning to develop a new law on bankruptcy of credit institutions to refine the 
process of dissolution, bankruptcy, and liquidation of credit institutions.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Viet Nam: 
 
The  financial  sector  plays  a  powerful,  through  indirect  role  in  reducing  poverty  by  facilitating  long-term 
economic growth. Growth, however, is not necessarily pro-poor and entails change, which the poor may 
often not be  well-equipped to cope with. A well-governed  financial sector that facilitates competition can 
help  make  growth  more  user–friendly  by  (i)  improving  access  to  savings,  credit,  and  insurance 
instruments, which enable the poor to cushion shocks as well as take advantage of opportunities created 
by change; and (ii) allowing for better terms on those instruments. 
 
A well-governed financial sector also reduces the likelihood and severity of financial and economic crises 
and consequently helps safeguard against a corresponding marked increase in the incidence of poverty. 
Balanced  financial  sector  development  can  promote  financial  system  stability  and  strengthening  by 
allowing  risks  to  be  more  evenly  spread  among  types  of  financial  institutions  and  spurring  competition 
between them.
